Specific Details: Green House Gas Emissions Target - Programme for Government
DPOs Lobbied: Micheál Martin|Taoiseach|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Leo Varadkar|Taoiseach|Department of the Taoiseach::Eamon Ryan|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Philip O'Callaghan|Special Adviser|Department of the Taoiseach
Subject Matter: Green House Gas Emissions Target - Programme for Government
Intended Results: That the next Government look at the way emissions are being calculated and accounted for before rushing headlong into environmental flag waving while ignoring scientific developments.::Acknowledge the recognition in the response from Fianna Fail /Fine Gael to the Green Party that biogenic methane must be treated differently.::That farmers are given credit for sequestration and the new Climate Bill has to factor in the latest Teagasc research which shows that Nitrous Oxide emissions from farming are being over counted,::That lessons are learned from the COVID-19 crisis. There are still the same number of animals on our planet, but emissions have dropped through the floor. There is a need to have serious re-look at how we are measuring and accounting for emissions,

They subsequently spoke on the phone and Richard invited Micheál Martin to visit the Devenish Lands at Dowth, our research farm in Meath.

Specific Details: The Chamber extended congratulations on election to the role of Taoiseach and highlighted how we believe that the current climate demands strong leadership adn decisive action. The Chamber is focused on helping companies in County Carlow and the South East through these challenges, offering support and guidance in many ways. It is imperative that we work to return our SME’s to a better position bef
DPOs Lobbied: Micheál Martin|An Taoiseach|Department of the Taoiseach
Subject Matter: The Chamber extended congratulations on election to the role of Taoiseach and highlighted how we believe that the current climate demands strong leadership adn decisive action.  While a range of supports have been put in place by the Government, more still needs to be done.  The Chamber is focused on helping companies in County Carlow and the South East through these challenges, offering support and guidance in many ways. It is imperative that we work to return our SME’s to a better position bef
Intended Results: We have seen supports in the form of loans and grants; however improved liquidity support measures are necessary. We recognise that there are demands from all areas for funding and support, especially now at a time of crisis. However, one of the best returns on investment is through supporting our SME’s who are in many ways the heart and souls of communities both rural and urban.

Lobbyist Name: County Wexford Chamber of Industry and Commerce CLG
Specific Details: Wexford has a lot of challenges in terms of its socio-economic standing, low levels of third level education, and traditional low levels of inward investment.  We see the provision of a University of the South East as critical to the development of the county, and hinterland.  We would ask that you would champion this cause, and make whatever resources are necessary available to secure a better future for our children and young people in particular.

Specific Details: Qualification for CRSS
DPOs Lobbied: Leo Varadkar|Minister|Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment::Micheál Martin|An Taoiseach|Department of the Taoiseach::Michael McGrath|Minister|Department of Public Expenditure and Reform::Brian Murphy|Chief of Staff|Department of the Taoiseach
Subject Matter: Qualification for CRSS
Intended Results: Following on from our recent letter we again called on the Minister to revisit the process for qualifying for CRSS for the many outlets that are strictly seasonal in serving food. Many of these outlets only recruit staff for that period of time. Revenue records will show that there are little or no returns for the off season period. These publicans are really desperate & need urgent assistance or their businesses will be lost for good without the benefit of CRSS over the coming weeks & months.

Specific Details: Proposal to lockdown the Hospitality Industry again before the New Year
DPOs Lobbied: Micheál Martin|An Taoiseach|Department of the Taoiseach::Leo Varadkar|An Tánaiste|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: Proposal to lockdown the Hospitality Industry again before the New Year
Intended Results: The announcement by the Taoiseach on the 6pm news that plans will be put in place to close the hospitality sector before the New Year is unacceptable and has created uncertainties for everyone in the sector. The fact that we will not know until the 22nd of December what date those plans will come into place adds to the uncertainty. We are calling on the Taoiseach & Tanaiste to give us certainty before the 22nd of the date for closure again and for how long.

Specific Details: Budget 2021 and covid 19 recovery
DPOs Lobbied: Eamon Ryan|Minister|Department of Climate Action, Communication Networks and Transport::Leo Varadkar|An Tánaiste|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Micheál Martin|An Taoiseach|Department of the Taoiseach
Subject Matter: Budget 2021 and covid 19 recovery
Intended Results: Ensuring the budget for 2021, and the recovery from COVID 19 is guided by just transition principles
Lobbying Activities:
Emails to Party leaders on 11 Dec to request that the budget and covid 19 recovery are guided by just transition principles, as agreed by a coalition of organisations with the following 6 principles. 
    Protect and invest in public services, prioritising public health and wellbeing
    Invest in people
    Deliver faster and fairer climate action and restore and protect nature
    Build solidarity and community across borders
    Ensure inclusive and participatory decision-making
    Redefine progress through a focus on wellbeing and sustainable development|Email|2-5

Specific Details: Calling for support for the Call to Action campaign by ITIC (Irish Tourism Industry Confederation).
DPOs Lobbied: Catherine Martin|Minister|Department of Tourism, Culture, Arts, Gaeltacht, Sport and Media::Leo Varadkar|Minister|Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment::Micheál Martin|An Taoiseach|Department of the Taoiseach::Damien English|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Martin Fraser|Secretary General|Department of the Taoiseach
Subject Matter: Calling for support for the Call to Action campaign by ITIC (Irish Tourism Industry Confederation).
Intended Results: (1) a comprehensive Covid-19 rapid testing regime to replace quarantine rule and green list and enable international travel to recommence safely. (2) Revision of the Employment Wage Subsidy Scheme, so that it is in line with terms of the Temporary Wage Subsidy Scheme. (3) VAT to be reduced to 9% for all tourism and hospitality businesses, and waiving of commercial rates to April 2021.  (4) Doubling of international marketing funds and tourism budgets.  (5) Business Continuity Grants for tourism

Specific Details: Letter to An Taoiseach seeing the establishment of a social dialogue process to discuss the climate emergency and to prioritise working with unions to develop plans to swiftly address the largest areas in which Ireland negatively impacts climate.
DPOs Lobbied: Micheál Martin|An Taoiseach|Department of the Taoiseach::Eamon Ryan|Minister|Department of Climate Action, Communication Networks and Transport
Subject Matter: Letter to An Taoiseach seeing the establishment of a social dialogue process to discuss the climate emergency and to prioritise working with unions to develop plans to swiftly address the largest areas in which Ireland negatively impacts climate.
Intended Results: again declare a climate emergency and to prioritise working with unions to develop plans to swiftly address the largest areas in which Ireland negatively impacts climate. Such issues would necessarily include decarbonising Ireland’s energy, incentivising the use of public transport through subsidising its use and developing a viable integrated transport network and encouraging all means of reducing daily commuting such as the introduction of a four-day week and working from home.
Lobbying Activities: Letter sent on 14th October 2020. Also copied to Minister for Communications, Climate Act and Environment.|Letter|1

Specific Details: 1.The roll out of the new Local Employment Services (LES) across the country by the Department of Employment and Social Protection (DEASP). The roll out plan currently excludes Cork County. 2. The new LEADER 2021-2027 Programme and the Transitional LEADER Programme which will bridge the gap between the previous LEADER Programme and the new LEADER Programme.
DPOs Lobbied: Micheál Martin|An Taoiseach|Department of the Taoiseach::Michael McGrath|Minister|Department of Public Expenditure and Reform
Subject Matter: 1.The roll out of the new Local Employment Services (LES) across the country by the Department of Employment and Social Protection (DEASP). The roll out plan currently excludes Cork County. 2. The new LEADER 2021-2027 Programme and the Transitional LEADER Programme which will bridge the gap between the previous LEADER Programme and the new LEADER Programme.
Intended Results: 1. The inclusion of Cork County in the roll out of the new LES across the country by the DEASP. Sufficient funds for County Cork in both the Transitional LEADER Programme and the new LEADER 2021-2027 Programme. Cork County had its LEADER budget cut by up to 70% in the LEADER 2016-2020 Programme.
Lobbying Activities:
Letter was issued to An Taoiseach on 3/12/2020 from the CEOs of all LDCs in Cork County. The following are two requests made in the letter:

'We have two requests in this context:
1. That Cork County, because of its geographic spread with a population of over 350,000 – should be offered a separate ‘Lot / Area’ contract in line with other regions in the country.
2. That our rural Local Development Companies that operate in Cork County are allowed to tender for this contract as part of a collaborative / collective tender.'|Letter|1::SECAD's CEO (Ryan Howard) and SECAD's Assistant CEO (Suzanne Kearney) met with Minister Michael McGrath to discuss two matters.
1. LEADER 2021-2027 the Transitional LEADER Programme - to ensure that there will be sufficient funding for County Cork for the new LEADER Programme and the Transitional Programme which will be in place from the end of LEADER 2016-2020 and the new LEADER Programme.
2. To include Cork County in the roll out of the new Local Employment Services (LES) by the DEASP. In communications received to date Cork County is not included in the 'areas/lots' to be tendered.|Meeting|1
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Mr. Ryan Howard - CEO and Ms. Suzanne Kearney - Assistant CEO

Specific Details: Government COVID 19 Guidelines for reopening the Economy for Casinos
DPOs Lobbied: Stephen Donnelly|Minister|Department of Health::Tony Holohan|Chief Medical Officer|Department of Health::Leo Varadkar|An Tánaiste|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Micheál Martin|An Taoiseach|Department of the Taoiseach::Ronan Glynn|Chief Medical Officer|Department of Health
Subject Matter: Government COVID 19 Guidelines for reopening the Economy for Casinos
Intended Results: To secure approval that casinos could re-open alongside wet pubs and bookmakers shops at level ll of the Government Guidelines.
Lobbying Activities:
The GLAI sought clarification regarding the criteria and analysis used to decide not to permit casinos to reopen at level 2 and to enable the GLAI to review whether the criteria and analysis applied was fair and accurate. 
Secondly, the GLAI sought engagement with the Minister and his department officials to show how the sector had since adopted measures to allay any public health concerns regarding the reopening of land based casinos. Specific Details: Invitation to: An Taoiseach ref: new strategy launch
DPOs Lobbied: Micheál Martin|An Taoiseach|Department of the Taoiseach
Subject Matter: Invitation to: An Taoiseach ref: new strategy launch
Intended Results: Engineers Ireland has a new Statement of Strategic Intent for the period 2021-2023 intended to guide our organisation in its work over that timeframe. We wished to invite the Taoiseach, Micheál Martin TD to hear first hand, the outline detail of our strategic intentions over the coming three years, and to address our members on governmental priority matters.  (Our membership would be key to the fulfillment, for example, of the ambition of Project Ireland 2040).

Lobbyist Name: Association of Visitor Experiences and Attractions CLG
Specific Details: 07.12.2020:  AVEA wrote to An Taoiseach Mícheál Martin to express  shock and frustration at the Department of An Taoiseach’s revision of the guidelines for the Visitor Experience and Attractions sector on 4th December, which was incompatible with guidelines originally published by Fáilte Ireland on 30th November.  The revisions to guided tours/experiences and to Santa experiences were in practical terms unworkable and changed with no notice.
DPOs Lobbied: Micheál Martin|An Taoiseach|Department of the Taoiseach
Subject Matter: 07.12.2020:  AVEA wrote to An Taoiseach Mícheál Martin to express  shock and frustration at the Department of An Taoiseach’s revision of the guidelines for the Visitor Experience and Attractions sector on 4th December, which was incompatible with guidelines originally published by Fáilte Ireland on 30th November.  The revisions to guided tours/experiences and to Santa experiences were in practical terms unworkable and changed with no notice.
Intended Results: A review of the unworkable changes to the guidelines and re-instatement of those originally issued by Fáilte Ireland on November 30th.  We also requested a meeting in order to provide the Department with a better understanding of our sector and the assurance that we have and can continue to deliver safe, controlled environments for visitors.

Specific Details: Government COVID 19 Guidelines for reopening the Economy for Casinos
DPOs Lobbied: Leo Varadkar|An Tánaiste|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Micheál Martin|An Taoiseach|Department of the Taoiseach
Subject Matter: Government COVID 19 Guidelines for reopening the Economy for Casinos
Intended Results: To secure approval that casinos could re-open alongside wet pubs and bookmakers shops at level ll of the Government Guidelines.
Lobbying Activities:
The GLAI sought clarification regarding the criteria and analysis used to decide not to permit casinos to reopen at level 2 and to enable the GLAI to review whether the criteria and analysis applied was fair and accurate. 
Secondly, the GLAI sought engagement to show how the sector could adopt measures to allay any public health concerns regarding the reopening of land based casinos. The GLAI sought amendments to the Government's public health guidelines that would allow casinos to re-open at level 2 alongside wet pubs.|Letter|2-5::The GLAI sought clarification regarding the criteria and analysis used to decide not to permit casinos to reopen at level 2 and to enable the GLAI to review whether the criteria and analysis applied was fair and accurate. 
Secondly, the GLAI sought engagement to show how the sector could adopt measures to allay any public health concerns regarding the reopening of land based casinos. The GLAI sought amendments to the Government's public health guidelines that would allow casinos to re-open at level 2 alongside wet pubs.|Email|1

Specific Details: To discuss the current level of COVID-19 restrictions and the Church’s desire to return to worship, in particular during the season of Lent and with the approach of Holy Week and Easter. Recognising the huge challenges the pandemic poses, the Archbishops emphasised they wish to continue supporting the public health message. They shared concern that life at present is particularly stressful and difficult for people to endure, emotionally, mentally and spiritually.
DPOs Lobbied: Micheál Martin|An Taoiseach|Department of the Taoiseach
Subject Matter: To discuss the current level of COVID-19 restrictions and the Church’s desire to return to worship, in particular during the season of Lent and with the approach of Holy Week and Easter. Recognising the huge challenges the pandemic poses, the Archbishops emphasised they wish to continue supporting the public health message. They shared concern that life at present is particularly stressful and difficult for people to endure, emotionally, mentally and spiritually.
Intended Results: Recognising the spiritual comfort and hope that participation in public worship brings, the Archbishops asked that public worship resume when an easing of restrictions is considered.  They expressed a strong desire that people might gather safely this year for the important ceremonies of Holy Week and Easter.  They also requested consideration of an increase in the number of the bereaved who may attend funeral Masses.
Lobbying Activities: A bilateral meeting between the four Catholic Archbishops and An Taoiseach, Mr Michéal Martin TD, took place on 19 February 2021.|Meeting|1
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Archbishop Eamon Martin DD, Archbishop Dermot Farrell DD, Archbishop Kieran O’Reilly DD and Archbishop Michael Neary DD

Specific Details: Hospitality Re-Opening on July 5th
DPOs Lobbied: Micheál Martin|An Taoiseach|Department of the Taoiseach::Leo Varadkar|An Tánaiste|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Deirdre Gillane|Chief of Staff|Department of the Taoiseach::Brian Murphy|Chief of Staff|Department of the Taoiseach::Declan Hughes|Assistant Secretary|Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Subject Matter: Hospitality Re-Opening on July 5th
Intended Results: There has been mixed messaging regarding the re-opening of indoor hospitality on July 5th leaving the final decision until July 2nd. This is totally unacceptable and shows no respect to either the publicans or their employees. Staff must be re-engaged and retrained, stock much be purchased, cold rooms and refrigeration must be put back on. How can that be done between a Friday and a Monday? We call on the Taoiseach to dispel any doubts and to reopen as planned on July 5th.

Specific Details: Operational Guidelines for the Hospitality Sector
DPOs Lobbied: Martin Fraser|Secretary General|Department of the Taoiseach::John Kelly|Acting Assistant Secretary|Department of Tourism, Culture, Arts, Gaeltacht, Sport and Media::Declan Hughes|Assistant Secretary|Department of Business, Enterprise and Innovation::Micheál Martin|An Taoiseach|Department of the Taoiseach::Leo Varadkar|An Tánaiste|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Catherine Martin|Minister|Department of Tourism, Culture, Arts, Gaeltacht, Sport and Media::Brian Murphy|Chief of Staff|Department of the Taoiseach::Deirdre Gillane|Chief of Staff|Department of the Taoiseach
Subject Matter: Operational Guidelines for the Hospitality Sector
Intended Results: The VFI believe the 105 minute time limit should be removed and customers should be allowed be served at the bar counter when indoor service resumes on July 5th. We further believe that given more people will be vaccinated at the beginning of August more restrictions should be lifted with all restrictions lifted from 30th August as the vaccination rollout to all adults in Ireland is scheduled to be fully completed by then..

The findings of the report and its recommendations were discussed at both virtual meetings.|Virtual Meeting|2-5::KPMG prepared a report regarding the viability and affordability of apartment development in Ireland, including recommendations to support viability and affordability in this regard. The report was publicly launched on 14th July 2021.|Submission|1

Specific Details: Irish delegation to the COP26 Climate Change Conference 2021
DPOs Lobbied: Eamon Ryan|Minister|Department of Environment, Climate and Communications::Micheál Martin|An Taoiseach|Department of the Taoiseach::Leo Varadkar|An Tánaiste|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: Irish delegation to the COP26 Climate Change Conference 2021
Intended Results: That Ireland would support the creation of an international loss and damage fund, with new sources of finance  which are in line with the ‘polluter pays’ principle.::In the COP26 negotiations, that Ireland would support the end of the use of public money to subsidise fossil fuel exploration, extraction and use::In the COP26 negotiations, that Ireland would support a requirement for national action plans to meet obligations with sectoral annual targets for emissions reduction::In the COP26 negotiations, that Ireland would progressively reduce dependence on fossil fuels, specifically rejecting the construction of an LNG terminal and the use of imported fracked gas::Domestically, that Ireland would protect and foster biodiversity::Domestically, that Ireland would commit to a transformation of transport with a prioritisation of infrastructure to support walking, cycling and public transport over electric cars::Domestically, that Ireland would commit to ensuring a just transition, which protects those who are most vulnerable and those whose livelihoods will be most impacted by the changes required::Domestically, that Ireland would promote increased investment in renewable energy sources::Domestically, that Ireland would ensure that policies across all areas of government reflect our commitment to climate justice
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Rev Dr Ivan Patterson and Bishop Brendan Leahy

Specific Details: NHI noted the recent developments regarding Sláintecare. Stated concerns regarding the slow pace in implementation of reform within our health services are of concern too for NHI and mirror challenges presented within the nursing home sector. NHI has expressed strong concern regarding implementation of structural reform within the sector, as per Covid19 Expert Panel. The Expert Panel strategic recommendations are not being progressed with the expediency they require.

Subject Matter: NHI noted the recent developments regarding Sláintecare. Stated concerns regarding the slow pace in implementation of reform within our health services are of concern too for NHI and mirror challenges presented within the nursing home sector. NHI has expressed strong concern regarding implementation of structural reform within the sector, as per Covid19 Expert Panel. The Expert Panel strategic recommendations are not being progressed with the expediency they require.
Intended Results: To meet with An Taoiseach and Minister Donnelly in relation to Sláintecare rollout. Furthermore to discuss the Expert Panel and long overdue review of Fair Deal pricing mechanism, which provide opportunity for Government to implement a fit-for-purpose support structure for nursing home resident care.

Specific Details: The urgent need to convene a Citizens’ Assembly on drugs
DPOs Lobbied: Micheál Martin|Taoiseach|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: The urgent need to convene a Citizens’ Assembly on drugs
Intended Results: This is why we are collectively calling on the Government to convene a Citizens’ Assembly on drugs so that the Irish people have an opportunity to consider drug policy reform. We are calling on the Department of the Taoiseach to take responsibility for its delivery. The Assembly would allow participants to examine the international, European, national, and local research on drug use and drug policy.::he Assembly would present an opportunity to consider the perspectives of representative groups, advocacy groups, experts, and drug policy makers. It would also, importantly, allow the Irish people to consider the many contributing factors to drug use and addiction. We are calling for an Assembly which will consider drug use, policy, and reform broadly. It’s essential that the Assembly is nottoo limited in scope orrestricted to a healthcare framework
Current or Former DPOs: Lynne Ruane|Senator|Seanad

Specific Details: Support in relation to Ukrainian refugees coming to Ireland
DPOs Lobbied: Micheál Martin|An Taoiseach|Department of the Taoiseach
Subject Matter: Support in relation to Ukrainian refugees coming to Ireland
Intended Results: A letter was sent to the office of An Taoiseach in relation to the war in Ukraine, with the main purpose of informing the Taoiseach that our Institution was willing to assist the Government in any way in relation to the crisis and in particular in supporting refugees coming to Ireland from Ukraine.::In our letter, we said that as an association of engineers, we were deeply shocked by the Russian invasion and attack on Ukraine which had initiated a humanitarian crisis for the people of the country.::We said that we had issued a statement and placed it on our website;  that we were particularly keen to support any engineers coming from Ukraine including engineering students, and that the Irish Red Cross had reached out to us to ask us for help in assessing properties, pledged by the public in Ireland for Ukrainian refugees, and we were going to practically support that work.::We also told the Taoiseach that we informed our counterpart in Ukraine – the Union of Scientific and Engineering Associations of Ukraine – of our support.
Lobbying Activities:
The letter was signed by Caroline Spillane and by our President.
It was sent by email on 21 March 2022.|Letter|1
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Caroline Spillane, Director General of Engineers Ireland.

Specific Details: Convey concern at EU High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy/Vice-President EEAS Mr Josep Borrell Fontelles’ 20 January 2023 response to  parliamentary question entitled ‘Antisemitism in the Amnesty International Report on Israel’
DPOs Lobbied: Micheál Martin|Tánaiste and Minister|Department of Foreign Affairs
Subject Matter: Convey concern at EU High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy/Vice-President EEAS Mr Josep Borrell Fontelles’ 20 January 2023 response to  parliamentary question entitled ‘Antisemitism in the Amnesty International Report on Israel’
Intended Results: Call on EU Ministers for Foreign Affairs, including Ireland’s, to echo call on HR/VP Borrell to retract his harmful response that rejected the finding of apartheid in Amnesty's report and implied that such criticism of Israel is anti-Semitic; again urge the Irish Government to unambiguously recognise the validity of the determination that Israel's policies and practices amount to the crime of apartheid, and take the steps recommended in our report.

Subject Matter: Heart failure and lung cancer policies

Specific Details: European Food Safety Authority - Welfare Recommendations
DPOs Lobbied: Micheál Martin|Taoiseach|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: European Food Safety Authority - Welfare Recommendations
Intended Results: To highlight the huge risk posed to our Irish poultry sector if recommendations made by EFSA to the EU Commission are implemented. This could potentially decimate the sector and result in 70% of chicken meat being imported into EU.::To highlight that Irish farmers are highly committed to complying with best practice but these proposals go too far. Countries we are importing from do not have the same standards as we have in Ireland. Increasing imports from outside the EU would be counterproductive from a welfare perspective.

Specific Details: EU-Australia Trade Agreement
DPOs Lobbied: Billy Kelleher|MEP|European Parliament::Micheál Martin|Tánaiste and Minister|Department of Foreign Affairs
Subject Matter: EU-Australia Trade Agreement
Intended Results: To highlight the concern felt by Irish farmers that the pending conclusion to the negotiations on the EU-Australia Trade Agreement will lead to further concessions on beef and sheep meat.::To highlight that, as the biggest exporters of sheep meat in the world, Australia exported 284,000t of lamb in 2022, the attractiveness of the high value EU market is evident. In order to maintain the viability of this sensitive sector, which suffered an increase in total costs of 28% in 2022 (Ireland), the EU market cannot be further eroded by the addition of increased quota to Australian exports to the EU despite what Australian negotiators may request or expect.::That the average Irish suckler beef herd is 17 cows and this must be protected. Consumption of beef is falling in the EU (estimated by GIRA at -4.8% 2022-2027). This is not the time to grant increased quota to Australian imports whose high value beef products will undermine the EU producers' ability to achieve a profitable return.::Food inflationary pressures have affected affordability of beef in the EU market and the livestock sector will suffer further contraction if it is not supported and protected.::To highlight that EU farmers face two wars on the periphery of the EU market and increased commitments in the transition process of the Green Deal. The cumulative effect of EU trade deals adds to the impact Irish and EU farmers face following the UK bilateral trade deals attracting additional product of beef and sheep meat onto the EU market.::The price of Irish beef has fallen €1/kg below the UK price, as a result of lower beef purchases in the UK following the increased access to cheaper high value cuts from such trade deals, in particular, Australia.::To point out that Ireland seeks to provide a viable future for young farmers, however, their future is threatened by trade deals that can threaten the economic sustainability of Irish farms. Irish and EU sheep farmers satisfy numerous goals of the Farm to Fork Strategy and they continue to implement environmentally sustainable measures however they will not survive if agriculture is used as barter in the end-game conclusion of an EU-Australia trade deal.
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Tim Cullinan IFA President, Liam MacHale IFA Director of EU Affairs, Kevin Comiskey IFA Sheep Chair, Brendan Golden IFA Beef Chair
